verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:1
verses.text: Book  Wherein is described the god of Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:2
verses.text: He is shown to be utterly wanting in all the attributes of the true God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:3
verses.text: Whatever in times past we have wrought in opposition to Marcion, is from the present moment no longer to be accounted of.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:4
verses.text: It is a new work which we are undertaking in lieu of the old one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:5
verses.text: My original tract, as too hurriedly composed, I had subsequently superseded by a fuller treatise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:6
verses.text: This latter I lost, before it was completely published, by the fraud of a person who was then a brother, but became afterwards an apostate.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:7
verses.text: He, as it happened, had transcribed a portion of it, full of mistakes, and then published it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:8
verses.text: The necessity thus arose for an amended work; and the occasion of the new edition induced me to make a considerable addition to the treatise.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:9
verses.text: This present text, therefore, of my work—which is the third as superseding the second, but henceforward to be considered the first instead of the third—renders a preface necessary to this issue of the tract itself that no reader may be perplexed, if he should by chance fall in with the various forms of it which are scattered about.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:10
verses.text: The Euxine Sea, as it is called, is self-contradictory in its nature, and deceptive in its name.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:11
verses.text: As you would not account it hospitable from its situation, so is it severed from our more civilised waters by a certain stigma which attaches to its barbarous character.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:12
verses.text: The fiercest nations inhabit it, if indeed it can be called habitation, when life is passed in waggons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:13
verses.text: They have no fixed abode; their life has no germ of civilization; they indulge their libidinous desires without restraint, and for the most part naked.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:14
verses.text: Moreover, when they gratify secret lust, they hang up their quivers on their car-yokes, to warn off the curious and rash observer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:15
verses.text: Thus without a blush do they prostitute their weapons of war.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:16
verses.text: The dead bodies of their parents they cut up with their sheep, and devour at their feasts.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:17
verses.text: They who have not died so as to become food for others, are thought to have died an accursed death.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:18
verses.text: Their women are not by their sex softened to modesty.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:19
verses.text: They uncover the breast, from which they suspend their battle-axes, and prefer warfare to marriage.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:20
verses.text: In their climate, too, there is the same rude nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:21
verses.text: The day-time is never clear, the sun never cheerful; the sky is uniformly cloudy; the whole year is wintry; the only wind that blows is the angry North.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:22
verses.text: Waters melt only by fires; their rivers flow not by reason of the ice; their mountains are covered with heaps of snow.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:23
verses.text: All things are torpid, all stiff with cold.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:24
verses.text: Nothing there has the glow of life, but that ferocity which has given to scenic plays their stories of the sacrifices of the Taurians, and the loves of the Colchians, and the torments of the Caucasus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:25
verses.text: Nothing, however, in Pontus is so barbarous and sad as the fact that Marcion was born there, fouler than any Scythian, more roving than the waggon-life of the Sarmatian, more inhuman than the Massagete, more audacious than an Amazon, darker than the cloud, (of Pontus) colder than its winter, more brittle than its ice, more deceitful than the Ister, more craggy than Caucasus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:26
verses.text: Nay more, the true Prometheus, Almighty God, is mangled by Marcion's blasphemies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:27
verses.text: Marcion is more savage than even the beasts of that barbarous region.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:28
verses.text: For what beaver was ever a greater emasculator than he who has abolished the nuptial bond?  What Pontic mouse ever had such gnawing powers as he who has gnawed the Gospels to pieces? Verily, O Euxine, thou hast produced a monster more credible to philosophers than to Christians.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:29
verses.text: For the cynic Diogenes used to go about, lantern in hand, at mid-day to find a man; whereas Marcion has quenched the light of his faith, and so lost the God whom he had found.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:30
verses.text: His disciples will not deny that his first faith he held along with ourselves; a letter of his own proves this; so that for the future a heretic may from his case be designated as one who, forsaking that which was prior, afterwards chose out for himself that which was not in times past.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:31
verses.text: For in as far as what was delivered in times past and from the beginning will be held as truth, in so far will that be accounted heresy which is brought in later.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:32
verses.text: But another brief treatise will maintain this position against heretics, who ought to be refuted even without a consideration of their doctrines, on the ground that they are heretical by reason of the novelty of their opinions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 1:33
verses.text: Now, so far as any controversy is to be admitted, I will for the time (lest our compendious principle of novelty, being called in on all occasions to our aid, should be imputed to want of confidence) begin with setting forth our adversary's rule of belief, that it may escape no one what our main contention is to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:1
verses.text: The heretic of Pontus introduces two Gods, like the twin Symplegades of his own shipwreck: One whom it was impossible to deny, i-e: our Creator; and one whom he will never be able to prove, i-e: his own god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:2
verses.text: The unhappy man gained the first idea of his conceit from the simple passage of our Lord's saying, which has reference to human beings and not divine ones, wherein He disposes of those examples of a good tree and a corrupt one; how that "the good tree bringeth not forth corrupt fruit, neither the corrupt tree good fruit".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:3
verses.text: Which means, that an honest mind and good faith cannot produce evil deeds, any more than an evil disposition can produce good deeds.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:4
verses.text: Now (like many other persons now-a-days, especially those who have an heretical proclivity), while morbidly brooding over the question of the origin of evil, his perception became blunted by the very irregularity of his researches; and when he found the Creator declaring, "I am He that createth evil," inasmuch as he had already concluded from other arguments, which are satisfactory to every perverted mind, that God is the author of evil, so he now applied to the Creator the figure of the corrupt tree bringing forth evil fruit, that is, moral evil, and then presumed that there ought to be another god, after the analogy of the good tree producing its good fruit.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:5
verses.text: Accordingly, finding in Christ a different disposition, as it were—one of a simple and pure benevolence—differing from the Creator, he readily argued that in his Christ had been revealed a new and strange divinity; and then with a little leaven he leavened the whole lump of the faith, flavouring it with the acidity of his own heresy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:6
verses.text: He had, moreover, in one Cerdon an abettor of this blasphemy,—a circumstance which made them the more readily think that they saw most clearly their two gods, blind though they were; for, in truth, they had not seen the one God with soundness of faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:7
verses.text: To men of diseased vision even one lamp looks like many.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:8
verses.text: One of his gods, therefore, whom he was obliged to acknowledge, he destroyed by defaming his attributes in the matter of evil; the other, whom he laboured so hard to devise, he constructed, laying his foundation in the principle of good.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 2:9
verses.text: In what articles he arranged these natures, we show by our own refutations of them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:1
verses.text: The principal, and indeed the whole, contention lies in the point of number: whether two Gods may be admitted, by poetic licence (if they must be), or pictorial fancy, or by the third process, as we must now add, of heretical pravity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:2
verses.text: But the Christian verity has distinctly declared this principle, "God is not, if He is not one;" because we more properly believe that that has no existence which is not as it ought to be.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:3
verses.text: In order, however, that you may know that God is one, ask what God is, and you will find Him to be not otherwise than one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:4
verses.text: So far as a human being can form a definition of God, I adduce one which the conscience of all men will also acknowledge,—that God is the great Supreme existing in eternity, unbegotten, unmade without beginning, without end.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:5
verses.text: For such a condition as this must needs be ascribed to that eternity which makes God to be the great Supreme, because for such a purpose as this is this very attribute in God; and so on as to the other qualities:  so that God is the great Supreme in form and in reason, and in might and in power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:6
verses.text: Now, since all are agreed on this point (because nobody will deny that God is in some sense the great Supreme, except the man who shall be able to pronounce the opposite opinion, that God is but some inferior being, in order that he may deny God by robbing Him of an attribute of God), what must be the condition of the great Supreme Himself? Surely it must be that nothing is equal to Him, i-e: that there is no other great supreme; because, if there were, He would have an equal; and if He had an equal, He would be no longer the great Supreme, now that the condition and (so to say) our law, which permits nothing to be equal to the great Supreme, is subverted.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:7
verses.text: That Being, then, which is the great Supreme, must needs be unique, by having no equal, and so not ceasing to be the great Supreme.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:8
verses.text: Therefore He will not otherwise exist than by the condition whereby He has His being; that is, by His absolute uniqueness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:9
verses.text: Since, then, God is the great Supreme, our Christian verity has rightly declared, "God is not, if He is not one".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:10
verses.text: Not as if we doubted His being God, by saying, He is not, if He is not one; but because we define Him, in whose being we thoroughly believe, to be that without which He is not God; that is to say, the great Supreme.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:11
verses.text: But then the great Supreme must needs be unique.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:12
verses.text: This Unique Being, therefore, will be God—not otherwise God than as the great Supreme; and not otherwise the great Supreme than as having no equal; and not otherwise having no equal than as being Unique.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:13
verses.text: Whatever other god, then, you may introduce, you will at least be unable to maintain his divinity under any other guise, than by ascribing to him too the property of Godhead—both eternity and supremacy over all.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 3:14
verses.text: How, therefore, can two great Supremes co-exist, when this is the attribute of the Supreme Being, to have no equal,—an attribute which belongs to One alone, and can by no means exist in two?.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:1
verses.text: But some one may contend that two great Supremes may exist, distinct and separate in their own departments; and may even adduce, as an example, the kingdoms of the world, which, though they are so many in number, are yet supreme in their several regions.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:2
verses.text: Such a man will suppose that human circumstances are always comparable with divine ones.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:3
verses.text: Now, if this mode of reasoning be at all tolerable, what is to prevent our introducing, I will not say a third god or a fourth, but as many as there are kings of the earth? Now it is God that is in question, whose main property it is to admit of no comparison with Himself.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:4
verses.text: Nature itself, therefore, if not an Isaiah, or rather God speaking by Isaiah, will deprecatingly ask, "To whom will ye liken me?" Human circumstances may perhaps be compared with divine ones, but they may not be with God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:5
verses.text: God is one thing, and what belongs to God is another thing.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:6
verses.text: Once more: you who apply the example of a king, as a great supreme, take care that you can use it properly.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:7
verses.text: For although a king is supreme on his throne next to God, he is still inferior to God; and when he is compared with God, he will be dislodged from that great supremacy which is transferred to God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:8
verses.text: Now, this being the case, how will you employ in a comparison with God an object as your example, which fails in all the purposes which belong to a comparison? Why, when supreme power among kings cannot evidently be multifarious, but only unique and singular, is an exception made in the case of Him (of all others) who is King of kings, and (from the exceeding greatness of His power, and the subjection of all other ranks to Him) the very summit, as it were, of dominion? But even in the case of rulers of that other form of government, where they one by one preside in a union of authority, if with their petty prerogatives of royalty, so to say, they be brought on all points into such a comparison with one another as shall make it clear which of them is superior in the essential features and powers of royalty, it must needs follow that the supreme majesty will redound to one alone,—all the others being gradually, by the issue of the comparison, removed and excluded from the supreme authority.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:9
verses.text: Thus, although, when spread out in several hands, supreme authority seems to be multifarious, yet in its own powers, nature, and condition, it is unique.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:10
verses.text: It follows, then, that if two gods are compared, as two kings and two supreme authorities, the concentration of authority must necessarily, according to the meaning of the comparison, be conceded to one of the two; because it is clear from his own superiority that he is the supreme, his rival being now vanquished, and proved to be not the greater, however great.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:11
verses.text: Now, from this failure of his rival, the other is unique in power, possessing a certain solitude, as it were, in his singular pre-eminence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 4:12
verses.text: The inevitable conclusion at which we arrive, then, on this point is this: either we must deny that God is the great Supreme, which no wise man will allow himself to do; or say that God has no one else with whom to share His power.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:1
verses.text: But on what principle did Marcion confine his supreme powers to two? I would first ask, If there be two, why not more? Because if number be compatible with the substance of Deity, the richer you make it in number the better.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:2
verses.text: Valentinus was more consistent and more liberal; for he, having once imagined two deities, Bythos and Sige, poured forth a swarm of divine essences, a brood of no less than thirty aeons, like the sow of aeneas.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:3
verses.text: Now, whatever principle refuses to admit several supreme beings, the same must reject even two, for there is plurality in the very lowest number after one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:4
verses.text: After unity, number commences.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:5
verses.text: So, again, the same principle which could admit two could admit more.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:6
verses.text: After two, multitude begins, now that one is exceeded.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:7
verses.text: In short, we feel that reason herself expressly forbids the belief in more gods than one, because the self-same rule lays down one God and not two, which declares that God must be a Being to which, as the great Supreme, nothing is equal; and that Being to which nothing is equal must, moreover, be unique.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:8
verses.text: But further, what can be the use or advantage in supposing two supreme beings, two co-ordinate powers? What numerical difference could there be when two equals differ not from one?  For that thing which is the same in two is one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:9
verses.text: Even if there were several equals, all would be just as much one, because, as equals, they would not differ one from another.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:10
verses.text: So, if of two beings neither differs from the other, since both of them are on the supposition supreme, both being gods, neither of them is more excellent than the other; and so, having no pre-eminence, their numerical distinction has no reason in it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:11
verses.text: Number, moreover, in the Deity ought to be consistent with the highest reason, or else His worship would be brought into doubt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:12
verses.text: For consider now, if, when I saw two Gods before me (who, being both Supreme Beings, were equal to each other), I were to worship them both, what should I be doing? I should be much afraid that the abundance of my homage would be deemed superstition rather than piety.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:13
verses.text: Because, as both of them are so equal and are both included in either of the two, I might serve them both acceptably in only one; and by this very means I should attest their equality and unity, provided that I worshipped them mutually the one in the other, because in the one both are present to me.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 5:14
verses.text: If I were to worship one of the two, I should be equally conscious of seeming to pour contempt on the uselessness of a numerical distinction, which was superfluous, because it indicated no difference; in other words, I should think it the safer course to worship neither of these two Gods than one of them with some scruple of conscience, or both of them to none effect.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:1
verses.text: Thus far our discussion seems to imply that Marcion makes his two gods equal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:2
verses.text: For while we have been maintaining that God ought to be believed as the one only great Supreme Being, excluding from Him every possibility of equality, we have treated of these topics on the assumption of two equal Gods; but nevertheless, by teaching that no equals can exist according to the law of the Supreme Being, we have sufficiently affirmed the impossibility that two equals should exist.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:3
verses.text: For the rest, however, we know full well that Marcion makes his gods unequal: one judicial, harsh, mighty in war; the other mild, placid, and simply good and excellent.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:4
verses.text: Let us with similar care consider also this aspect of the question, whether diversity (in the Godhead) can at any rate contain two, since equality therein failed to do so.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:5
verses.text: Here again the same rule about the great Supreme will protect us, inasmuch as it settles the entire condition of the Godhead.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:6
verses.text: Now, challenging, and in a certain sense arresting the meaning of our adversary, who does not deny that the Creator is God, I most fairly object against him that he has no room for any diversity in his gods, because, having once confessed that they are on a par, he cannot now pronounce them different; not indeed that human beings may not be very different under the same designation, but because the Divine Being can be neither said nor believed to be God, except as the great Supreme.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:7
verses.text: Since, therefore, he is obliged to acknowledge that the God whom he does not deny is the great Supreme, it is inadmissible that he should predicate of the Supreme Being such a diminution as should subject Him to another Supreme Being.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:8
verses.text: For He ceases (to be Supreme), if He becomes subject to any.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:9
verses.text: Besides, it is not the characteristic of God to cease from any attribute of His divinity—say, from His supremacy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:10
verses.text: For at this rate the supremacy would be endangered even in Marcion's more powerful god, if it were capable of depreciation in the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:11
verses.text: When, therefore, two gods are pronounced to be two great Supremes, it must needs follow that neither of them is greater or less than the other, neither of them loftier or lowlier than the other.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:12
verses.text: If you deny him to be God whom you call inferior, you deny the supremacy of this inferior being.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:13
verses.text: But when you confessed both gods to be divine, you confessed them both to be supreme.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:14
verses.text: Nothing will you be able to take away from either of them; nothing will you be able to add.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 6:15
verses.text: By allowing their divinity, you have denied their diversity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:1
verses.text: But this argument you will try to shake with an objection from the name of God, by alleging that that name is a vague one, and applied to other beings also; as it is written, "God standeth in the congregation of the mighty; He judgeth among the gods".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:2
verses.text: And again, "I have said, Ye are gods".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:3
verses.text: As therefore the attribute of supremacy would be inappropriate to these, although they are called gods, so is it to the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:4
verses.text: This is a foolish objection; and my answer to it is, that its author fails to consider that quite as strong an objection might be urged against the (superior) god of Marcion: he too is called god, but is not on that account proved to be divine, as neither are angels nor men, the Creator's handiwork.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:5
verses.text: If an identity of names affords a presumption in support of equality of condition, how often do worthless menials strut insolently in the names of kings—your Alexanders, Caesars, and Pompeys! This fact, however, does not detract from the real attributes of the royal persons.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:6
verses.text: Nay more, the very idols of the Gentiles are called gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:7
verses.text: Yet not one of them is divine because he is called a god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:8
verses.text: It is not, therefore, for the name of god, for its sound or its written form, that I am claiming the supremacy in the Creator, but for the essence to which the name belongs; and when I find that essence alone is unbegotten and unmade—alone eternal, and the maker of all things—it is not to its name, but its state, not to its designation, but its condition, that I ascribe and appropriate the attribute of the supremacy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:9
verses.text: And so, because the essence to which I ascribe it has come to be called god, you suppose that I ascribe it to the name, because I must needs use a name to express the essence, of which indeed that Being consists who is called God, and who is accounted the great Supreme because of His essence, not from His name.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:10
verses.text: In short, Marcion himself, when he imputes this character to his god, imputes it to the nature, not to the word.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:11
verses.text: That supremacy, then, which we ascribe to God in consideration of His essence, and not because of His name, ought, as we maintain, to be equal in both the beings who consist of that substance for which the name of God is given; because, in as far as they are called gods (i-e: supreme beings, on the strength, of course, of their unbegotten and eternal, and therefore great and supreme essence), in so far the attribute of being the great Supreme cannot be regarded as less or worse in one than in another great Supreme.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:12
verses.text: If the happiness, and sublimity, and perfection of the Supreme Being shall hold good of Marcion's god, it will equally so of ours; and if not of ours, it will equally not hold of Marcion's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:13
verses.text: Therefore two supreme beings will be neither equal nor unequal: not equal, because the principle which we have just expounded, that the Supreme Being admits of no comparison with Himself, forbids it; not unequal, because another principle meets us respecting the Supreme Being, that He is capable of no diminution.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:14
verses.text: So, Marcion, you are caught in the midst of your own Pontic tide.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:15
verses.text: The waves of truth overwhelm you on every side.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:16
verses.text: You can neither set up equal gods nor unequal ones.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:17
verses.text: For there are not two; so far as the question of number is properly concerned.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 7:18
verses.text: Although the whole matter of the two gods is at issue, we have yet confined our discussion to certain bounds, within which we shall now have to contend about separate peculiarities.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:1
verses.text: In the first place, how arrogantly do the Marcionites build up their stupid system, bringing forward a new god, as if we were ashamed of the old one! So schoolboys are proud of their new shoes, but their old master beats their strutting vanity out of them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:2
verses.text: Now when I hear of a new god, who, in the old world and in the old time and under the old god was unknown and unheard of; whom, (accounted as no one through such long centuries back, and ancient in men's very ignorance of him), a certain "Jesus Christ," and none else revealed; whom Christ revealed, they say—Christ himself new, according to them, even, in ancient names—I feel grateful for this conceit of theirs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:3
verses.text: For by its help I shall at once be able to prove the heresy of their tenet of a new deity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:4
verses.text: It will turn out to be such a novelty as has made gods even for the heathen by some new and yet again and ever new title for each several deification.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:5
verses.text: What new god is there, except a false one? Not even Saturn will be proved to be a god by all his ancient fame, because it was a novel pretence which some time or other produced even him, when it first gave him godship.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:6
verses.text: On the contrary, living and perfect Deity has its origin neither in novelty nor in antiquity, but in its own true nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:7
verses.text: Eternity has no time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:8
verses.text: It is itself all time.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:9
verses.text: It acts; it cannot then suffer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:10
verses.text: It cannot be born, therefore it lacks age.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:11
verses.text: God, if old, forfeits the eternity that is to come; if new, the eternity which is past.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:12
verses.text: The newness bears witness to a beginning; the oldness threatens an end.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 8:13
verses.text: God, moreover, is as independent of beginning and end as He is of time, which is only the arbiter and measurer of a beginning and an end.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:1
verses.text: Now I know full well by what perceptive faculty they boast of their new god; even their knowledge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:2
verses.text: It is, however, this very discovery of a novel thing—so striking to common minds—as well as the natural gratification which is inherent in novelty, that I wanted to refute, and thence further to challenge a proof of this unknown god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:3
verses.text: For him whom by their knowledge they present to us as new, they prove to have been unknown previous to that knowledge.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:4
verses.text: Let us keep within the strict limits and measure of our argument.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:5
verses.text: Convince me there could have been an unknown god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:6
verses.text: I find, no doubt, that altars have been lavished on unknown gods; that, however, is the idolatry of Athens.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:7
verses.text: And on uncertain gods; but that, too, is only Roman superstition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:8
verses.text: Furthermore, uncertain gods are not well known, because no certainty about them exists; and because of this uncertainty they are therefore unknown.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:9
verses.text: Now, which of these two titles shall we carve for Marcion's god? Both, I suppose, as for a being who is still uncertain, and was formerly unknown.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:10
verses.text: For inasmuch as the Creator, being a known God, caused him to be unknown; so, as being a certain God, he made him to be uncertain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:11
verses.text: But I will not go so far out of my way, as to say: If God was unknown and concealed, He was overshadowed in such a region of darkness, as must have been itself new and unknown, and be even now likewise uncertain—some immense region indeed, one undoubtedly greater than the God whom it concealed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:12
verses.text: But I will briefly state my subject, and afterwards most fully pursue it, promising that God neither could have been, nor ought to have been, unknown.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:13
verses.text: Could not have been, because of His greatness; ought not to have been, because of His goodness, especially as He is (supposed, by Marcion) more excellent in both these attributes than our Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:14
verses.text: Since, however, I observe that in some points the proof of every new and heretofore unknown god ought, for its test, to be compared to the form of the Creator, it will be my duty first of all to show that this very course is adopted by me in a settled plan, such as I might with greater confidence use in support of my argument.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:15
verses.text: Before every other consideration, (let me ask) how it happens that you, who acknowledge the Creator to be God, and from your knowledge confess Him to be prior in existence, do not know that the other god should be examined by you in exactly the same course of investigation which has taught you how to find out a god in the first case? Every prior thing has furnished the rule for the latter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:16
verses.text: In the present question two gods are propounded, the unknown and the known.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:17
verses.text: Concerning the known there is no question.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:18
verses.text: It is plain that He exists, else He would not be known.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:19
verses.text: The dispute is concerning the unknown god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:20
verses.text: Possibly he has no existence; because, if he had, he would have been known.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:21
verses.text: Now that which, so long as it is unknown, is an object to be questioned, is an uncertainty so long as it remains thus questionable; and all the while it is in this state of uncertainty, it possibly has no existence at all.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:22
verses.text: You have a god who is so far certain, as he is known; and uncertain, as unknown.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:23
verses.text: This being the case, does it appear to you to be justly defensible, that uncertainties should be submitted for proof to the rule, and form, and standard of certainties?  Now, if to the subject before us, which is in itself full of uncertainty thus far, there be applied also arguments derived from uncertainties, we shall be involved in such a series of questions arising out of our treatment of these same uncertain arguments, as shall by reason of their uncertainty be dangerous to the faith, and we shall drift into those insoluble questions which the apostle has no affection for.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:24
verses.text: If, again, in things wherein there is found a diversity of condition, they shall prejudge, as no doubt they will, uncertain, doubtful, and intricate points, by the certain, undoubted, and clear sides of their rule, it will probably happen that (those points) will not be submitted to the standard of certainties for determination, as being freed by the diversity of their essential condition from the application of such a standard in all other respects.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:25
verses.text: As, therefore, it is two gods which are the subject of our proposition, their essential condition must be the same in both.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:26
verses.text: For, as concerns their divinity, they are both unbegotten, unmade, eternal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:27
verses.text: This will be their essential condition.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:28
verses.text: All other points Marcion himself seems to have made light of, for he has placed them in a different category.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:29
verses.text: They are subsequent in the order of treatment; indeed, they will not have to be brought into the discussion, since on the essential condition there is no dispute.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:30
verses.text: Now there is this absence of our dispute, because they are both of them gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:31
verses.text: Those things, therefore, whose community of condition is evident, will, when brought to a test on the ground of that common condition, have to be submitted, although they are uncertain, to the standard of those certainties with which they are classed in the community of their essential condition, so as on this account to share also in their manner of proof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 9:32
verses.text: I shall therefore contend with the greatest confidence that he is not God who is to-day uncertain, because he has been hitherto unknown; for of whomsoever it is evident that he is God, from this very fact it is (equally) evident, that he never has been unknown, and therefore never uncertain.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:1
verses.text: For indeed, as the Creator of all things, He was from the beginning discovered equally with them, they having been themselves manifested that He might become known as God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:2
verses.text: For although Moses, some long while afterwards, seems to have been the first to introduce the knowledge of the God of the universe in the temple of his writings, yet the birthday of that knowledge must not on that account be reckoned from the Pentateuch.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:3
verses.text: For the volume of Moses does not at all initiate the knowledge of the Creator, but from the first gives out that it is to be traced from Paradise and Adam, not from Egypt and Moses.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:4
verses.text: The greater part, therefore, of the human race, although they knew not even the name of Moses, much less his writings, yet knew the God of Moses; and even when idolatry overshadowed the world with its extreme prevalence, men still spoke of Him separately by His own name as God, and the God of gods, and said, "If God grant," and, "As God pleases," and, "I commend you to God".

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:5
verses.text: Reflect, then, whether they knew Him, of whom they testify that He can do all things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:6
verses.text: To none of the writings of Moses do they owe this.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:7
verses.text: The soul was before prophecy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:8
verses.text: From the beginning the knowledge of God is the dowry of the soul, one and the same amongst the Egyptians, and the Syrians, and the tribes of Pontus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:9
verses.text: For their souls call the God of the Jews their God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:10
verses.text: Do not, O barbarian heretic, put Abraham before the world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:11
verses.text: Even if the Creator had been the God of one family, He was yet not later than your god; even in Pontus was He known before him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:12
verses.text: Take then your standard from Him who came first: from the Certain (must be judged) the uncertain; from the Known the unknown.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:13
verses.text: Never shall God be hidden, never shall God be wanting.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:14
verses.text: Always shall He be understood, always be heard, nay even seen, in whatsoever way He shall wish.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:15
verses.text: God has for His witnesses this whole being of ours, and this universe wherein we dwell.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 10:16
verses.text: He is thus, because not unknown, proved to be both God and the only One, although another still tries hard to make out his claim.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:1
verses.text: The Evidence for God External to Him; But the External Creation Which Yields This Evidence is Really Not Extraneous, for All Things are God's.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:2
verses.text: Marcion's God, Having Nothing to Show for Himself, No God at All.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:3
verses.text: Marcion's Scheme Absurdly Defective, Not Furnishing Evidence for His New God's Existence, Which Should at Least Be Able to Compete with the Full Evidence of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:4
verses.text: And justly so, they say.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:5
verses.text: For who is there that is less well known by his own (inherent) qualities than by strange ones? No one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:6
verses.text: Well, I keep to this statement.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:7
verses.text: How could anything be strange to God, to whom, if He were personally existent, nothing would be strange? For this is the attribute of God, that all things are His, and all things belong to Him; or else this question would not so readily be heard from us: What has He to do with things strange to Him?—a point which will be more fully noticed in its proper place.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:8
verses.text: It is now sufficient to observe, that no one is proved to exist to whom nothing is proved to belong.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:9
verses.text: For as the Creator is shown to be God, God without any doubt, from the fact that all things are His, and nothing is strange to Him; so the rival god is seen to be no god, from the circumstance that nothing is his, and all things are therefore strange to him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:10
verses.text: Since, then, the universe belongs to the Creator, I see no room for any other god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:11
verses.text: All things are full of their Author, and occupied by Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:12
verses.text: If in created beings there be any portion of space anywhere void of Deity, the void will be of a false deity clearly.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:13
verses.text: By falsehood the truth is made clear.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:14
verses.text: Why cannot the vast crowd of false gods somewhere find room for Marcion's god?  This, therefore, I insist upon, from the character of the Creator, that God must have been known from the works of some world peculiarly His own, both in its human constituents, and the rest of its organic life; when even the error of the world has presumed to call gods those men whom it sometimes acknowledges, on the ground that in every such case something is seen which provides for the uses and advantages of life.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:15
verses.text: Accordingly, this also was believed from the character of God to be a divine function; namely, to teach or point out what is convenient and needful in human concerns.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:16
verses.text: So completely has the authority which has given influence to a false divinity been borrowed from that source, whence it had previously flowed forth to the true one.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:17
verses.text: One stray vegetable at least Marcion's god ought to have produced as his own; so might he be preached up as a new Triptolemus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:18
verses.text: Or else state some reason which shall be worthy of a God, why he, supposing him to exist, created nothing; because he must, on supposition of his existence, have been a creator, on that very principle on which it is clear to us that our God is no otherwise existent, than as having been the Creator of this universe of ours.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:19
verses.text: For, once for all, the rule will hold good, that they cannot both acknowledge the Creator to be God, and also prove him divine whom they wish to be equally believed in as God, except they adjust him to the standard of Him whom they and all men hold to be God; which is this, that whereas no one doubts the Creator to be God on the express ground of His having made the universe, so, on the selfsame ground, no one ought to believe that he also is God who has made nothing—except, indeed, some good reason be forthcoming.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:20
verses.text: And this must needs be limited to one of two: he was either unwilling to create, or else unable.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:21
verses.text: There is no third reason.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:22
verses.text: Now, that he was unable, is a reason unworthy of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:23
verses.text: Whether to have been unwilling to be a worthy one, I want to inquire.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:24
verses.text: Tell me, Marcion, did your god wish himself to be recognised at any time or not? With what other purpose did he come down from heaven, and preach, and having suffered rise again from the dead, if it were not that he might be acknowledged? And, doubtless, since he was acknowledged, he willed it.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:25
verses.text: For no circumstance could have happened to him, if he had been unwilling.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:26
verses.text: What indeed tended so greatly to the knowledge of himself, as his appearing in the humiliation of the flesh,—a degradation all the lower indeed if the flesh were only illusory? For it was all the more shameful if he, who brought on himself the Creator's curse by hanging on a tree, only pretended the assumption of a bodily substance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:27
verses.text: A far nobler foundation might he have laid for the knowledge of himself in some evidences of a creation of his own, especially when he had to become known in opposition to Him in whose territory he had remained unknown by any works from the beginning.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 11:28
verses.text: For how happens it that the Creator, although unaware, as the Marcionites aver, of any god being above Himself, and who used to declare even with an oath that He existed alone, should have guarded by such mighty works the knowledge of Himself, about which, on the assumption of His being alone without a rival, He might have spared Himself all care; while the Superior God, knowing all the while how well furnished in power His inferior rival was, should have made no provision at all towards getting Himself acknowledged? Whereas He ought to have produced works more illustrious and exalted still, in order that He might, after the Creator's standard, both be acknowledged as God from His works, and even by nobler deeds show Himself to be more potent and more gracious than the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:1
verses.text: Impossibility of Acknowledging God Without This External Evidence Of His Existence.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:2
verses.text: Marcion's Rejection of Such Evidence for His God Savours of Impudence and Malignity.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:3
verses.text: But even if we were able to allow that he exists, we should yet be bound to argue that he is without a cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:4
verses.text: For he who had nothing (to show for himself as proof of his existence), would be without a cause, since (such) proof is the whole cause that there exists some person to whom the proof belongs.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:5
verses.text: Now, in as far as nothing ought to be without a cause, that is, without a proof (because if it be without a cause, it is all one as if it be not, not having the very proof which is the cause of a thing), in so far shall I more worthily believe that God does not exist, than that He exists without a cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:6
verses.text: For he is without a cause who has not a cause by reason of not having a proof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:7
verses.text: God, however, ought not to be without a cause, that is to say, without a proof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:8
verses.text: Thus, as often as I show that He exists without a cause, although (I allow that) He exists, I do really determine this, that He does not exist; because, if He had existed, He could not have existed altogether without a cause.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:9
verses.text: So, too, even in regard to faith itself, I say that he seeks to obtain it without cause from man, who is otherwise accustomed to believe in God from the idea he gets of Him from the testimony of His works: (without cause, I repeat,) because he has provided no such proof as that whereby man has acquired the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:10
verses.text: For although most persons believe in Him, they do not believe at once by unaided reason, without having some token of Deity in works worthy of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 12:11
verses.text: And so upon this ground of inactivity and lack of works he is guilty both of impudence and malignity:  of impudence, in aspiring after a belief which is not due to him, and for which he has provided no foundation; of malignity, in having brought many persons under the charge of unbelief by furnishing to them no groundwork for their faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:1
verses.text: The Marcionites Depreciate the Creation, Which, However, is a Worthy Witness of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:2
verses.text: This Worthiness Illustrated by References to the Heathen Philosophers, Who Were Apt to Invest the Several Parts of Creation with Divine Attributes.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:3
verses.text: While we are expelling from this rank (of Deity) a god who has no evidence to show for himself which is so proper and God-worthy as the testimony of the Creator, Marcion's most shameless followers with haughty impertinence fall upon the Creator's works to destroy them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:4
verses.text: To be sure, say they, the world is a grand work, worthy of a God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:5
verses.text: Then is the Creator not at all a God? By all means He is God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:6
verses.text: Therefore the world is not unworthy of God, for God has made nothing unworthy of Himself; although it was for man, and not for Himself, that He made the world, (and) although every work is less than its maker.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:7
verses.text: And yet, if to have been the author of our creation, such as it is, be unworthy of God, how much more unworthy of Him is it to have created absolutely nothing at all!—not even a production which, although unworthy, might yet have encouraged the hope of some better attempt.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:8
verses.text: To say somewhat, then, concerning the alleged unworthiness of this world's fabric, to which among the Greeks also is assigned a name of ornament and grace, not of sordidness, those very professors of wisdom, from whose genius every heresy derives its spirit, called the said unworthy elements divine; as Thales did water, Heraclitus fire, Anaximenes air, Anaximander all the heavenly bodies, Strato the sky and earth, Zeno the air and ether, and Plato the stars, which he calls a fiery kind of gods; whilst concerning the world, when they considered indeed its magnitude, and strength, and power, and honour, and glory,—the abundance, too, the regularity, and law of those individual elements which contribute to the production, the nourishment, the ripening, and the reproduction of all things,—the majority of the philosophers hesitated to assign a beginning and an end to the said world, lest its constituent elements, great as they undoubtedly are, should fail to be regarded as divine, which are objects of worship with the Persian magi, the Egyptian hierophants, and the Indian gymnosophists.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:9
verses.text: The very superstition of the crowd, inspired by the common idolatry, when ashamed of the names and fables of their ancient dead borne by their idols, has recourse to the interpretation of natural objects, and so with much ingenuity cloaks its own disgrace, figuratively reducing Jupiter to a heated substance, and Juno to an aërial one (according to the literal sense of the Greek words); Vesta, in like manner, to fire, and the Muses to waters, and the Great Mother to the earth, mowed as to its crops, ploughed up with lusty arms, and watered with baths.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:10
verses.text: Thus Osiris also, whenever he is buried, and looked for to come to life again, and with joy recovered, is an emblem of the regularity wherewith the fruits of the ground return, and the elements recover life, and the year comes round; as also the lions of Mithras are philosophical sacraments of arid and scorched nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:11
verses.text: It is, indeed, enough for me that natural elements, foremost in site and state, should have been more readily regarded as divine than as unworthy of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:12
verses.text: I will, however, come down to humbler objects.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 13:13
verses.text: A single floweret from the hedgerow, I say not from the meadows; a single little shellfish from any sea, I say not from the Red Sea; a single stray wing of a moorfowl, I say nothing of the peacock,—will, I presume, prove to you that the Creator was but a sorry artificer!.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:1
verses.text: All Portions of Creation Attest the Excellence of the Creator, Whom Marcion Vilifies.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:2
verses.text: His Inconsistency Herein Exposed.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:3
verses.text: Marcion's Own God Did Not Hesitate to Use the Creator's Works in Instituting His Own Religion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:4
verses.text: Now, when you make merry with those minuter animals, which their glorious Maker has purposely endued with a profusion of instincts and resources,—thereby teaching us that greatness has its proofs in lowliness, just as (according to the apostle) there is power even in infirmity—imitate, if you can, the cells of the bee, the hills of the ant, the webs of the spider, and the threads of the silkworm; endure, too, if you know how, those very creatures which infest your couch and house, the poisonous ejections of the blister-beetle, the spikes of the fly, and the gnat's sheath and sting.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:5
verses.text: What of the greater animals, when the small ones so affect you with pleasure or pain, that you cannot even in their case despise their Creator? Finally, take a circuit round your own self; survey man within and without.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:6
verses.text: Even this handiwork of our God will be pleasing to you, inasmuch as your own lord, that better god, loved it so well, and for your sake was at the pains of descending from the third heaven to these poverty-stricken elements, and for the same reason was actually crucified in this sorry apartment of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:7
verses.text: Indeed, up to the present time, he has not disdained the water which the Creator made wherewith he washes his people; nor the oil with which he anoints them; nor that union of honey and milk wherewithal he gives them the nourishment of children; nor the bread by which he represents his own proper body, thus requiring in his very sacraments the "beggarly elements" of the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:8
verses.text: You, however, are a disciple above his master, and a servant above his lord; you have a higher reach of discernment than his; you destroy what he requires.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:9
verses.text: I wish to examine whether you are at least honest in this, so as to have no longing for those things which you destroy.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:10
verses.text: You are an enemy to the sky, and yet you are glad to catch its freshness in your houses.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:11
verses.text: You disparage the earth, although the elemental parent of your own flesh, as if it were your undoubted enemy, and yet you extract from it all its fatness for your food.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:12
verses.text: The sea, too, you reprobate, but are continually using its produce, which you account the more sacred diet.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:13
verses.text: If I should offer you a rose, you will not disdain its Maker.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:14
verses.text: You hypocrite, however much of abstinence you use to show yourself a Marcionite, that is, a repudiator of your Maker (for if the world displeased you, such abstinence ought to have been affected by you as a martyrdom), you will have to associate yourself with the Creator's material production, into what element soever you shall be dissolved.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 14:15
verses.text: How hard is this obstinacy of yours! You vilify the things in which you both live and die.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:1
verses.text: The Lateness of the Revelation of Marcion's God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:2
verses.text: The Question of the Place Occupied by the Rival Deities.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:3
verses.text: Instead of Two Gods, Marcion Really (Although, as It Would Seem, Unconsciously) Had Nine Gods in His System.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:4
verses.text: After all, or, if you like, before all, since you have said that he has a creation of his own, and his own world, and his own sky; we shall see, indeed, about that third heaven, when we come to discuss even your own apostle.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:5
verses.text: Meanwhile, whatever is the (created) substance, it ought at any rate to have made its appearance in company with its own god.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:6
verses.text: But now, how happens it that the Lord has been revealed since the twelfth year of Tiberius Caesar, while no creation of His at all has been discovered up to the fifteenth of the Emperor Severus; although, as being more excellent than the paltry works of the Creator, it should certainly have ceased to conceal itself, when its lord and author no longer lies hid? I ask, therefore, if it was unable to manifest itself in this world, how did its Lord appear in this world? If this world received its Lord, why was it not able to receive the created substance, unless perchance it was greater than its Lord? But now there arises a question about place, having reference both to the world above and to the God thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:7
verses.text: For, behold, if he has his own world beneath him, above the Creator, he has certainly fixed it in a position, the space of which was empty between his own feet and the Creator's head.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:8
verses.text: Therefore God both Himself occupied local space, and caused the world to occupy local space; and this local space, too, will be greater than God and the world together.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:9
verses.text: For in no case is that which contains not greater than that which is contained.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:10
verses.text: And indeed we must look well to it that no small patches be left here and there vacant, in which some third god also may be able with a world of his own to foist himself in.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:11
verses.text: Now, begin to reckon up your gods.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:12
verses.text: There will be local space for a god, not only as being greater than God, but as being also unbegotten and unmade, and therefore eternal, and equal to God, in which God has ever been.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:13
verses.text: Then, inasmuch as He too has fabricated a world out of some underlying material which is unbegotten, and unmade, and contemporaneous with God, just as Marcion holds of the Creator, you reduce this likewise to the dignity of that local space which has enclosed two gods, both God and matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:14
verses.text: For matter also is a god according to the rule of Deity, being (to be sure) unbegotten, and unmade, and eternal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:15
verses.text: If, however, it was out of nothing that he made his world, this also (our heretic) will be obliged to predicate of the Creator, to whom he subordinates matter in the substance of the world.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:16
verses.text: But it will be only right that he too should have made his world out of matter, because the same process occurred to him as God which lay before the Creator as equally God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:17
verses.text: And thus you may, if you please, reckon up so far, three gods as Marcion's,—the Maker, local space, and matter.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:18
verses.text: Furthermore, he in like manner makes the Creator a god in local space, which is itself to be appraised on a precisely identical scale of dignity; and to Him as its lord he subordinates matter, which is notwithstanding unbegotten, and unmade, and by reason hereof eternal.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:19
verses.text: With this matter he further associates evil, an unbegotten principle with an unbegotten object, an unmade with an unmade, and an eternal with an eternal; so here he makes a fourth God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:20
verses.text: Accordingly you have three substances of Deity in the higher instances, and in the lower ones four.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 15:21
verses.text: When to these are added their Christs—the one which appeared in the time of Tiberius, the other which is promised by the Creator—Marcion suffers a manifest wrong from those persons who assume that he holds two gods, whereas he implies no less than nine, though he knows it not.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:1
verses.text: Marcion Assumes the Existence of Two Gods from the Antithesis Between Things Visible and Things Invisible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:2
verses.text: This Antithetical Principle in Fact Characteristic of the Works of the Creator, the One God—Maker of All Things Visible and Invisible.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:3
verses.text: Since, then, that other world does not appear, nor its god either, the only resource left to them is to divide things into the two classes of visible and invisible, with two gods for their authors, and so to claim the invisible for their own, (the supreme) God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:4
verses.text: But who, except an heretical spirit, could ever bring his mind to believe that the invisible part of creation belongs to him who had previously displayed no visible thing, rather than to Him who, by His operation on the visible world, produced a belief in the invisible also, since it is far more reasonable to give one's assent after some samples (of a work) than after none? We shall see to what author even (your favourite) apostle attributes the invisible creation, when we come to examine him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:5
verses.text: At present (we withhold his testimony), for we are for the most part engaged in preparing the way, by means of common sense and fair arguments, for a belief in the future support of the Scriptures also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:6
verses.text: We affirm, then, that this diversity of things visible and invisible must on this ground be attributed to the Creator, even because the whole of His work consists of diversities—of things corporeal and incorporeal; of animate and inanimate; of vocal and mute of moveable and stationary; of productive and sterile; of arid and moist; of hot and cold.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:7
verses.text: Man, too, is himself similarly tempered with diversity, both in his body and in his sensation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:8
verses.text: Some of his members are strong, others weak; some comely, others uncomely; some twofold, others unique; some like, others unlike.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:9
verses.text: In like manner there is diversity also in his sensation: now joy, then anxiety; now love, then hatred; now anger, then calmness.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:10
verses.text: Since this is the case, inasmuch as the whole of this creation of ours has been fashioned with a reciprocal rivalry amongst its several parts, the invisible ones are due to the visible, and not to be ascribed to any other author than Him to whom their counterparts are imputed, marking as they do diversity in the Creator Himself, who orders what He forbade, and forbids what He ordered; who also strikes and heals.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 16:11
verses.text: Why do they take Him to be uniform in one class of things alone, as the Creator of visible things, and only them; whereas He ought to be believed to have created both the visible and the invisible, in just the same way as life and death, or as evil things and peace? And verily, if the invisible creatures are greater than the visible, which are in their own sphere great, so also is it fitting that the greater should be His to whom the great belong; because neither the great, nor indeed the greater, can be suitable property for one who seems to possess not even the smallest things.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:1
verses.text: Not Enough, as the Marcionites Pretend, that the Supreme God Should Rescue Man; He Must Also Have Created Him.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:2
verses.text: The Existence of God Proved by His Creation, a Prior Consideration to His Character.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:3
verses.text: Pressed by these arguments, they exclaim: One work is sufficient for our god; he has delivered man by his supreme and most excellent goodness, which is preferable to (the creation of) all the locusts.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:4
verses.text: What superior god is this, of whom it has not been possible to find any work so great as the man of the lesser god! Now without doubt the first thing you have to do is to prove that he exists, after the same manner that the existence of God must ordinarily be proved—by his works; and only after that by his good deeds.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:5
verses.text: For the first question is, Whether he exists? and then, What is his character? The former is to be tested by his works, the other by the beneficence of them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:6
verses.text: It does not simply follow that he exists, because he is said to have wrought deliverance for man; but only after it shall have been settled that he exists, will there be room for saying that he has affected this liberation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:7
verses.text: And even this point also must have its own evidence, because it may be quite possible both that he has existence, and yet has not wrought the alleged deliverance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:8
verses.text: Now in that section of our work which concerned the question of the unknown god, two points were made clear enough—both that he had created nothing:  and that he ought to have been a creator, in order to be known by his works; because, if he had existed, he ought to have been known, and that too from the beginning of things; for it was not fit that God should have lain hid.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:9
verses.text: It will be necessary that I should revert to the very trunk of that question of the unknown god, that I may strike off into some of its other branches also.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:10
verses.text: For it will be first of all proper to inquire, Why he, who afterwards brought himself into notice, did so—so late, and not at the very first? From creatures, with which as God he was indeed so closely connected (and the closer this connection was, the greater was his goodness), he ought never to have been hidden.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:11
verses.text: For it cannot be pretended that there was not either any means of arriving at the knowledge of God, or a good reason for it, when from the beginning man was in the world, for whom the deliverance is now come; as was also that malevolence of the Creator, in opposition to which the good God has wrought the deliverance.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:12
verses.text: He was therefore either ignorant of the good reason for and means of his own necessary manifestation, or doubted them; or else was either unable or unwilling to encounter them.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:13
verses.text: All these alternatives are unworthy of God, especially the supreme and best.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 17:14
verses.text: This topic, however, we shall afterwards more fully treat, with a condemnation of the tardy manifestation; we at present simply point it out.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:1
verses.text: Notwithstanding Their Conceits, the God of the Marcionites Fails in the Vouchers Both of Created Evidence and of Adequate Revelation.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:2
verses.text: Well, then, he has now advanced into notice, just when he willed, when he could, when the destined hour arrived.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:3
verses.text: For perhaps he was hindered hitherto by his leading star, or some weird malignants, or Saturn in quadrature, or Mars at the trine.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:4
verses.text: The Marcionites are very strongly addicted to astrology; nor do they blush to get their livelihood by help of the very stars which were made by the Creator (whom they depreciate).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:5
verses.text: We must here also treat of the quality of the (new) revelation; whether Marcion's supreme god has become known in a way worthy of him, so as to secure the proof of his existence: and in the way of truth, so that he may be believed to be the very being who had been already proved to have been revealed in a manner worthy of his character.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:6
verses.text: For things which are worthy of God will prove the existence of God.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:7
verses.text: We maintain that God must first be known from nature, and afterwards authenticated by instruction: from nature by His works; by instruction, through His revealed announcements.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:8
verses.text: Now, in a case where nature is excluded, no natural means (of knowledge) are furnished.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:9
verses.text: He ought, therefore, to have carefully supplied a revelation of himself, even by announcements, especially as he had to be revealed in opposition to One who, after so many and so great works, both of creation and revealed announcement, had with difficulty succeeded in satisfying men's faith.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:10
verses.text: In what manner, therefore, has the revelation been made? If by man's conjectural guesses, do not say that God can possibly become known in any other way than by Himself, and appeal not only to the standard of the Creator, but to the conditions both of God's greatness and man's littleness; so that man seem not by any possibility to be greater than God, by having somehow drawn Him out into public recognition, when He was Himself unwilling to become known by His own energies, although man's littleness has been able, according to experiments all over the world, more easily to fashion for itself gods, than to follow the true God whom men now understand by nature.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:11
verses.text: As for the rest, if man shall be thus able to devise a god,—as Romulus did Consus, and Tatius Cloacina, and Hostilius Fear, and Metellus Alburnus, and a certain authority some time since Antinous,—the same accomplishment may be allowed to others.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 18:12
verses.text: As for us, we have found our pilot in Marcion, although not a king nor an emperor.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:1
verses.text: Jesus Christ, the Revealer of the Creator, Could Not Be the Same as Marcion's God, Who Was Only Made Known by the Heretic Some CXV.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:2
verses.text: Years After Christ, and That, Too, on a Principle Utterly Unsuited to the Teaching of Jesus Christ, i-e:, the Opposition Between the Law and the Gospels.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:3
verses.text: Well, but our god, say the Marcionites, although he did not manifest himself from the beginning and by means of the creation, has yet revealed himself in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:4
verses.text: A book will be devoted to Christ, treating of His entire state; for it is desirable that these subject-matters should be distinguished one from another, in order that they may receive a fuller and more methodical treatment.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:5
verses.text: Meanwhile it will be sufficient if, at this stage of the question, I show—and that but briefly—that Christ Jesus is the revealer of none other god but the Creator.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:6
verses.text: In the fifteenth year of Tiberius, Christ Jesus vouchsafed to come down from heaven, as the spirit of saving health.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:7
verses.text: I cared not to inquire, indeed, in what particular year of the elder Antoninus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:8
verses.text: He who had so gracious a purpose did rather, like a pestilential sirocco, exhale this health or salvation, which Marcion teaches from his Pontus.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:9
verses.text: Of this teacher there is no doubt that he is a heretic of the Antonine period, impious under the pious.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:10
verses.text: Now, from Tiberius to Antoninus Pius, there are about  years and -/ months.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:11
verses.text: Just such an interval do they place between Christ and Marcion.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:12
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as Marcion, as we have shown, first introduced this god to notice in the time of Antoninus, the matter becomes at once clear, if you are a shrewd observer.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:13
verses.text: The dates already decide the case, that he who came to light for the first time in the reign of Antoninus, did not appear in that of Tiberius; in other words, that the God of the Antonine period was not the God of the Tiberian; and consequently, that he whom Marcion has plainly preached for the first time, was not revealed by Christ (who announced His revelation as early as the reign of Tiberius).

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:14
verses.text: Now, to prove clearly what remains of the argument, I shall draw materials from my very adversaries.

verses.name: Tertullian: Against Marcion Book I 19:15
